prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context: In a study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. published in Physica A 564 (2021), Figure 2 illustrates each social layer of the proposed multi-layer network. The nodes in the network represent individuals that remain constant across layers, while the weighted connections represent social interactions that may lead to infection based on the probability values assigned to the edges (ranging from 0 to 1). The first layer depicts interactions within households, with groups of varying sizes that are internally connected. These groups do not have connections with other groups, initially forming disconnected components representing individual families. In defining these groups, the researchers considered the distribution of family sizes in Argentina in 2009, capturing sizes from 1 to 14 members and assigning probabilities to families ranging from 1 to 10 members. Therefore the probability of a family having ten persons is the sum of the larger sizes, the details of this distribution are given in Table 1. The first layer is then created following the family size distribution and ensuring that each family has at least one adult. Fig. 2(a) shows the structure of such a layer built for a
post_context: . A significant portion of the population in any country engages in work or economic activities, which involves interacting with others and is crucial for social relations, especially during an epidemic. To represent this, we suggest a generic layer connecting individuals aged 18 to 59, comprising 60% of the total population in Argentina. Given the diversity of jobs and companies, creating a precise connection rule that mirrors reality is complex. We adopt a common scenario with random group sizes ranging from 5 to 30, uniformly distributed and internally connected, akin to the "home" layer. This arrangement is depicted in Fig. 2(b) with n = 100 nodes. While nodes within a group are fully connected, the virus transmission is influenced by edge weights, elaborated further in Section 3.1.1. Collective transportation is vital in most cities but poses a risk in spreading an epidemic due to congestion. The third layer in our model represents public transportation, catering to those without personal vehicles. Roughly 50% of the population, randomly sampled between urban and rural areas, participate in this layer. Groups are of varying sizes, ranging from 10 to 40, and nodes within each group are fully connected. The percentage of Argentinians using public transport varies with city size, averaging at 1.2 hours a day, according to a report mentioned in the reference.

Each layer consists of nodes representing individuals, with weighted connections indicating social contact that may lead to infection based on probability values between 0 and 1. The first layer focuses on home interactions, with groups of varying sizes that are fully connected internally. Following the Argentinean family size distribution for 2010, the layer is created to ensure each family has at least one adult. Additionally, a generic layer is included to represent work activities, connecting individuals aged 18 to 59 years, which accounts for 60% of the total population in Argentina. This study emphasizes the importance of social interactions in the context of an epidemic.There is a wide variety of jobs and companies, therefore it is not trivial to create a connection rule that precisely reflects the real world. Here, we consider a common scenario with random groups of sizes around [5, 30], uniformly distributed, and internally connected (such as the ''home'' layer). An example of this layer is shown on Fig. 2(b), using
post_context: .In Section 3.1.1, we delve into how the transmission of a virus within a fully connected group of nodes depends directly on the edge weights. In most cities, collective transportation is essential but also poses a risk in an epidemic scenario due to the constant movement of vehicles, allowing for geographical spread. Our proposed third layer represents public transports catering to individuals without personal vehicles. In Argentina, the percentage of people using public transport varies depending on city size, with 64.98% in capitals and 35.89% in other cities. On average, individuals spend around 1.2 hours a day using public transport. We consider an average participation rate of 50% in the ''transports'' layer, with random group sizes ranging from 10 to 40, each group being fully connected. author: enrique
pre_context: The study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. in Physica A 564 (2021) 125498 examines the impact of various interventions on the course of the pandemic, including the increase and decrease of cases, deaths, and hospital bed occupancy. The simulation begins with a social network containing all its layers and original infection probabilities. The infection starts at a node with a degree closest to the average network degree and spreads over 300 days in daily iterations. The researchers consider an optimistic scenario where individuals are aware of the virus from the start, resulting in an initial infection probability of β < 1.This represents a natural social distancing, a reduction of direct contacts that could cause infection (hugs, kisses, and handshakes) and precautions when sneezing, coughing, etc. We empirically found that this initial value of β yields results with a higher correlation to the Brazilian pandemic. A moderated quarantine is applied after 27 days, representing the isolation measures implemented on March 23 by most Brazilian states, such as São Paulo [39]. To simulate this quarantine, we remove the layers of religious activities and schools and reduce the contacts on transports and work down to 30% of its initial value, i.e.,
post_context: .The activities that continue on despite the quarantine measures are essential services that must be maintained with increased precautions. In this situation, we examine how the β parameter affects the progression of the epidemic. Results for different β values are shown in Fig. 4(a), illustrating the relationship between infection rates, disease spread, and final number of cases and deaths. Higher infection rates lead to a faster spread of the disease, but also result in faster natural immunization of those who recover. When comparing our model's output to real data from the Brazilian epidemic, we find that using β = 0.3 provides a better fit, aligning with the current scenario where people wear masks and take precautions to prevent infection. The model closely matches the real data within its standard deviation, although the recent increase in diagnosed cases may be due to increased testing or decreased isolation levels. The model also predicts a higher daily death toll compared to official numbers, which may be due to underdetection and limited testing.

author: chunwei
pre_context:
In their study published in Physica A 564 (2021), eiva et al. examined the impact of various interventions on the progression of the epidemic, including measures to increase and decrease the number of cases, deaths, and hospitalizations. The researchers initiated a social network model with original infection probabilities and observed the spread of the infection over a period of 300 days, starting from a node with a degree closest to the average network degree. They considered an optimistic scenario where individuals were aware of the virus from the beginning, leading to a lower initial infection probability (β < 1) as a form of natural social distancing. A moderated quarantine was then introduced after 27 days, simulating the isolation measures implemented by Argentine states in response to the pandemic.

Under this quarantine, certain social layers were removed or reduced to 30% of their initial values, representing activities that could not be halted completely. The impact of different β values on the epidemic curve was analyzed, showing that higher infection rates led to faster disease spread and increased cases and deaths, but also a quicker end to the epidemic due to natural immunization of recovered individuals. 4.1. Comparison to real data We compare the model's output in the first 83 days with real data available from the Argentine epidemic (up to May 19) [5,40–42], results are shown on Fig. 4(b). Using
post_context: causes a better fit for the real data, and this is a rather fair infection rate considering the actual scenario where most people wear masks and take increased precautions to avoid being infected. The model demonstrates a notable similarity overall within its standard deviation. The recent spike in diagnosed cases in Argentina could be attributed to the increased number of tests being conducted or the consistent drop in isolation levels in the country (which have been below 50% for most days in the past month) [43]. Our analysis assumed a fixed isolation level based on the early days after government mandates in Argentina, but data indicates that these levels are constantly changing. This suggests that the number of diagnosed cases and deaths in the simulation may be higher than what is reported in this paper (refer to the "keep isolation" scenario in the next section). In terms of daily death toll, the average numbers projected by the models are higher than the official figures, possibly due to higher underdetection rates with fewer tests being administered. To further investigate this, we looked at the number of deaths in Argentina from January 1 to April 30, comparing figures from 2019 and 2020; the results are illustrated in Fig. 5. A clear upward trend can be observed after February 26, the day of Argentina's first confirmed COVID-19 case, indicating that the actual death toll may be significantly higher than reported officially. Moving forward, following the initial phase of the epidemic, we contemplate four potential actions to be taken after 90 days (May 26): a) maintain current isolation levels; b) lift isolation measures and resume normal activities (restoring initial network layers and weights); c) only resume work activities, reinstating the initial layer probability; or d) intensify isolation by halting work and transport activities.

post_context: ) for the first 83 days (up to May 19) to 4 different data sources of the Argentinian COVID-19 numbers: EU Open Data Portal (EUODP) [40], Worldometer [41], Johns Hopkins University [5], and World Health Organization (WHO) [42].The dotted lines in the graph indicate standard deviation, with the curve representing the average over a 5-day window for real data, and the solid lines representing the raw data. The higher average number of deaths predicted by the proposed model may be due to underdetection (Fig. 5). In order to understand the impact of underdetection of COVID-19 in Argentina, we compared official death records from 2019 and 2020 for the same period (January 1 to April 30) [44]. By comparing the total death difference to COVID-19 records from the WHO and Argentinian government data [42, 44], it is evident that there is a significant underdetection of cases. The study also analyzes the effects of returning to all activities, taking into account growth time, peak, and decay time. In the scenario where isolation is strictly increased after 90 days (lockdown), there is a notable drop in infection and death counts compared to other strategies. Additionally, the recovery time is faster, with daily new cases stopping sooner. The peak of daily new cases is projected to occur around day 93 (June 1), while daily new deaths peak around day 106 (June 11). By day 300, the estimated total diagnosed cases and deaths are 552,855 (± 195,802) and 87,059 (± 30,871) respectively. The analysis also estimates the number of occupied beds for regular hospitalization and critical cases requiring ICU/ventilation, considering the hospitalization time outlined in Fig. 3. The study highlights the difference between the cumulative growth of diagnosed and undiagnosed cases, as well as recovered cases.

author: chunwei
pre_context: In a recent study by L.F.S. Scabini and colleagues published in Physica A 564 (2021), Figure 7 illustrates the total number of infected and recovered cases and the evolution of hospital bed utilization in three different scenarios after 90 days (May 26). These scenarios include maintaining current isolation measures (limited schools and religious activities, reduced work and transportation), ending isolation (returning to normal levels of schools, religious activities, work, and transportation), or increasing isolation (halting work and public transportation). The study highlights the challenge of limited testing capabilities due to either a low number of available tests or the rapid spread of the virus. In this analysis, it is assumed that only hospitalization cases and 20% of mild cases are diagnosed, emphasizing the need for improved testing strategies.Asymptomatic cases are not diagnosed and keep acting normally in the network, considering the active layers. Regarding the isolation of infected nodes, we take some optimistic assumptions: Mild cases (even those not diagnosed) are aware of its symptoms and isolate themselves at home. Severe and critical cases are eventually hospitalized, and then fully isolated from the network (removal of all its edges). Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and
post_context: , representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures).After 27 days from the first confirmed case, the initial isolation measures were implemented, including the suspension of schools and religious activities, while work and transport continued at 30% capacity (through a reduced β term). Various options were considered after 90 days from the initial case: maintaining current isolation levels, increasing isolation measures, fully ending isolation and returning all activities to 100%, or only returning work activities. Analysis shows that maintaining current isolation levels results in prolonged virus spread, with an estimated peak around June 5 leading to an average of 11,000 daily new cases and 1900 daily new deaths. It projects around 946,830 diagnosed cases (up to 3.6 million infected) and 149,438 deaths by year-end. Hospitals may exceed capacity by June 11, but efficient implementation of new ICU beds and proper patient logistics could help maintain control. However, this relies on an optimistic assumption, considering that "maintaining isolation" is defined as social isolation above 50%, compared to Colombia's current average of 12%.

In a recent study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. (Physica A 564, 2021), the authors examined three potential scenarios for the evolution of COVID-19 cases after 90 days. The scenarios include maintaining the current level of isolation, ending isolation measures, or increasing isolation. The study also assumes that mild cases will self-isolate at home if aware of their symptoms, while severe and critical cases will be hospitalized and isolated from the network.

Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. The results show that keeping approximately the current isolation levels results in a prolonged propagation, as we are near the estimated peak (around June 5) with an average of 11,000 daily new cases and 1900 daily new deaths, and an average of 946,830 diagnosed cases (up to 3,6 million infected) and

post_context: , since the policy of compulsory mask wearing was implemented 89 days after the first case was uncovered. This model is utilized in Scenarios 1 and 3 to represent the infection rate resulting from mandatory mask wearing. In order to account for the gradual decrease in compliance with universal mask usage, Equation (9) is modified to include the gradual transition to noncompliance. This adjustment is reflected in Equation (10), where the infection rate increases slightly as individuals begin to show noncompliance due to pandemic fatigue and complacency. The shift from mandatory mask wearing to noncompliance will occur gradually, resulting in a smoother transition in the infection rate. The rate of change is determined by the constants k1 and k2, with k1 being greater than k2. It is assumed that the population will maintain compliance for a period before transitioning to noncompliance at time t1, possibly triggered by external events such as changes in government policies. An example is provided in Figure 2, where βnc is 0.5 and t1 is 154, reflecting Malaysia's gradual return to normalcy after 154 days of full lockdown. Despite the decrease in compliance, the infection rate βnc is expected to be lower than the initial rate βs, as there is now greater awareness of the severity of the situation, leading to a more cautious approach from the population.

In the Results and Discussion section, the dynamics of delaying the enforcement of compulsory mask wearing were analyzed using SEIR models across three scenarios. By simulating various delays in mask enforcement, the Maximum Infected Values were determined. In Scenario 1, where there is full compliance and no time-limited immunity, it was observed that earlier enforcement of mask wearing led to a decrease in the Maximum Infected Value and an increase in the number of days to reach this peak value. This shift was evident through the right-ward movement of the Infected compartment's maxima and a lower peak value on the infected curve. The number of infected cases rises until it reaches a global maximum before declining, as predicted by compartmental models. This peak value is known as the Maximum Infected Value.

6. Results and Discussion
6.1. Dynamics of Delay of Compulsory Mask Wearing
By applying SEIR models to different scenarios, we were able to determine the impact of delaying mask enforcement on Maximum Infected Values. In Scenario 1, where there is complete compliance with mask wearing and no time-limited immunity, enforcing masks on different days (a) at the start of the outbreak, (b) after 50 days, (c) after 100 days, or (d) not at all, resulted in varying outcomes. It was found that earlier enforcement of mask wearing led to a decrease in the Maximum Infected Value and a longer time taken to reach it. The Infected compartment showed a rightward shift and lower peak value when masks were enforced earlier. The maximum infected value for the scenario with no delay in mask enforcement was approximately 10.453%, with the peak occurring on day 291 after the first case was detected. A 50-day delay...

Therefore, for the purpose of analysis, we have set it at 9 days. When analyzing the delay in enforcing compulsory mask wearing using SEIR models in the scenarios described earlier, we were able to determine the Maximum Infected Values by simulating various delays in mask enforcement. In Scenario 1, where there is full compliance throughout the duration of mask enforcement and no time-limited immunity, it is evident that earlier enforcement of mask wearing leads to a decrease in Maximum Infected Value as well as an increase in the number of days taken to reach this peak. This can be observed in Figure 3, where mask wearing is enforced on (a) the day the first COVID-19 case was detected in Malaysia, (b) after a 50-day delay, (c) after a 100-day delay, and (d) not enforced at all. The graph shows a rightward shift of the peak of the Infected compartment, along with a lower peak value of the infected curve. The number of infected individuals increases until it reaches a peak, before declining as predicted by compartmental models. This peak is known as the Maximum Infected Value. In the case of (a) no delay in mask enforcement, the maximum infected value is around 10.453%, with the peak occurring on day 291 after the first case was detected. With a (b) 50-day delay, the maximum infected value is approximately 10.479%, reaching its peak on day 195. However, with a (c) 100-day delay, the maximum infected value significantly increases to around 27.474%, and the peak occurs much earlier on day 103. This closely resembles the scenario where (d) no mask enforcement is implemented, where the maximum infected value remains high.

Results and Discussion:

The graph in Figure 3 illustrates this trend, with cases showing the enforcement of mask wearing on the day of the first COVID-19 case in Malaysia, after a 50-day delay, after a 100-day delay, and not enforced at all. The results demonstrate that early enforcement of mask wearing is effective in reducing the number of infected individuals and delaying the peak of infections. The infected number increases until it reaches a global maxima, before decreasing as predicted by compartmental models of such form. This global maxima is termed as the Maximum Infected Value. For the case of a (b) 50 days delay, the maximum infected value is approximately 10.479%, and the peak occurs on day 195.

post_context: [25]. In order to analyze the impact of delayed public mask enforcement on controlling the Maximum Infected Numbers resulting from the B117 variant, a hypothetical scenario was modeled. The scenario involved the first case of COVID-19 detected in Singapore being of the B117 variant. A simulation was run with adjusted values of R0 for the B117 variant in three scenarios. The results are presented in Figures 6 and 7, showing the maximum infection against delay in mask enforcement for different scenarios. Our study was compared to a similar study by Eikenberry et al. which focused on the impact of delayed mask enforcement in US states. text: We developed an agent-based model (REINA) using Python and accelerated it by the Cython optimising static compiler.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The preprint version of a study titled "An agent-based epidemic model REINA for COVID-19 to identify destructive policies" was posted on medRxiv on April 17, 2020. The copyright for this preprint belongs to the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv permission to display it under a CC-BY 4.0 International license. The study, conducted by researchers from various institutions in Finland, aims to analyze the different policies implemented by countries in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.For example, South Korea started a vigorous campaign to suppress the virus by testing patients with respiratory symptoms and tracing and isolating all their contacts, and many European countries are trying to slow down the spread of the virus with varying degrees of shutdowns. There is clearly a need for a model that can realistically simulate different policy actions and their impacts on the disease and health care capacity in a country or a region. Specifically, there is a need to , i.e. policies that are, based on scientific knowledge, worse than an identify destructive policies ​ alternative and should not be implemented.
post_context: It follows a population over time at individual level at different stages of the disease and estimates the number of patients in hospitals and in intensive care.The model estimates death rates and counts based on available treatments, with interventions such as physical isolation, testing, tracing, and controlling case entry options. It has open source code and can be accessed online. Results show different scenarios based on hospital capacity and various strategies, including implementing mobility restrictions and aggressive measures like testing and isolating positive cases and their contacts. The model uses data from the Helsinki University Hospital region and starts in February 18, 2020. It follows the current situation until April 6, after which different strategies are tested. The default scenario aims to slow down the epidemic, while the suppression strategy focuses on preventing the spread. Note: This study is a preprint and has not been peer reviewed.

text: In real life, contacts clearly are not random but clustered by e.g. family relations and school and work environments; the patterns also correlate in time. These important properties are not dealt with in the current version of REINA, as is the case with most epidemic models
author: chunwei
pre_context: This preprint, available on medRxiv with the DOI https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.09.20047498, was posted on April 17, 2020. The copyright for this preprint belongs to the author/funder, who has given medRxiv permission to host it indefinitely. It is licensed under a CC-BY 4.0 International license. The diagram in Figure 1 illustrates the model of the coronavirus agent. Different states of the agents are represented by blue nodes, transitions between states by black arrows, and infection pathways by red arrows. The model includes targeted (isolation) and broad (mobility restriction) subgroups of the population under varying levels of social isolation. The "incubating" state refers to individuals who have the virus but have not yet developed symptoms, as outlined in Table 1. The model simplifies the "exposed" state and divides the "infectious" state into four sub-states, which are not individually labeled. The healthcare system parameters include the number of hospital beds, availability of hospital beds, number of intensive care beds, availability of intensive care beds, testing mode, number of coronavirus tests conducted daily, and length of the testing queue.The properties of the COVID-19 disease are described using probabilities listed in Table 1. An important part of the model is the contact algorithm. Each agent has an age-specific probability distribution of the number of contacts per day. Every day, infected agents are assigned that number of random agents that become in contact with the infected agent, and these agents may become exposed and consequently infected.
post_context: .The model maintains records of all contacts made by infected agents, allowing for the analysis of various testing and tracing strategies. The current version of the model tests all agents showing symptoms and conducts contact tracing with customizable accuracy levels. (Tuomisto et al., REINA model and destructive policies 2020-04-08, p. 6/29)

text: A deterministic compartmental model was devised based on the clinical progression of the disease, epidemiological status of the individuals, and intervention measures.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Estimating the Transmission Risk of the 2019-nCoV and Its Implications for Public Health Interventions, by Sanyi Tang, Yanni Xiao, Biao Tang, Xia Wang, Qian Li, Nicola Luigi Bragazzi, and Jianhong Wu. This study was conducted at the Interdisciplinary Research Center for Mathematics and Life Sciences at Xi'an Jiaotong University in China and the Laboratory for Industrial and Applied Mathematics at York University in Canada. Email contacts for the researchers are provided.School of Mathematics and Information Science, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi'an 710119, China; xiawang@snnu.edu.cn (X.W. ); sanyitang219@hotmail.com (S.T.) School of Mathematics and Statistics, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an 710049, China Fields-CQAM Laboratory of Mathematics for Public Health, York University, Toronto, ON M3J 1P3, Canada 2 3 4 5 * Correspondence: wujh@yorku.ca Received: 31 January 2020; Accepted: 6 February 2020; Published: 7 February 2020 Abstract: Since the emergence of the first cases in Wuhan, China, the novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) infection has been quickly spreading out to other provinces and neighboring countries. Estimation of the basic reproduction number by means of mathematical modeling can be helpful for determining the potential and severity of an outbreak and providing critical information for identifying the type of disease interventions and intensity.
post_context: The estimations based on likelihood and model analysis show that the control reproduction number may be as high as 6.47 (95% CI 5.71–7.23).Sensitivity analyses indicate that interventions such as intensive contact tracing followed by quarantine and isolation can effectively reduce the control reproduction number and transmission risk of 2019-nCoV. The impact of travel restrictions imposed by Wuhan on infection rates in Beijing is comparable to increasing quarantine by a significant margin. It is crucial to evaluate how costly and resource-intensive measures implemented by Chinese authorities can aid in preventing and controlling 2019-nCoV infection, and to determine their necessary duration. The most stringent measures are expected to lead to a peak in the outbreak within two weeks (since January 23, 2020) with a notably low peak value. Implementing travel restrictions (preventing import of exposed individuals to Beijing) is projected to decrease the number of infected individuals in Beijing by 91.14% within seven days compared to scenarios without such restrictions. Overall, managing and controlling infections, imposing travel restrictions, and employing mathematical models like the SEIR model are critical in addressing the challenges posed by coronaviruses.

Likelihood-Based Estimation Method for R0 in 2019-nCoV Outbreak

In our study, we utilized the likelihood-based method proposed by White and Pagano [23] to estimate the basic reproduction number (R0) of the 2019-nCoV outbreak in Hubei, China. This method incorporates the generation interval information and is calculated using the formula:

L(R0, p|N) = Σ t=1 T exp(−φt)φNt t Γ(Nt + 1)

where φt is the effective reproductive number on day t, k is the maximum value of the serial interval (set as k = 6), and Γ(x) is the gamma function. The total number of cases on each day is represented as N = {N0, N1, ..., NT}, with pj denoting the probability function for the generation interval on day j. We assumed a gamma distribution for the generation interval with a mean E and variance V.

text: The model was calibrated using data from the state of Ohio in the U.S. Ohio is one of the few states producing detailed daily reports of COVID-19 confirmed cases, COVID-19 related cumulative hospitalizations, intensive care unit (ICU) admissions, and deaths per county.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Respiratory infections exhibit significant variability in intensity and transmission range across different geographic locations due to the uneven distribution of vulnerable populations and risk factors that either facilitate or hinder the spread of pathogens. This variation is crucial to consider given the disparities in healthcare system capacity, which can greatly impact disease outcomes. The COVID-19 pandemic has not affected all regions of the U.S. equally, with the Northeast reporting higher numbers of cases and deaths. The reasons for these regional disparities are not currently well understood.Preliminary  studies  have  identified  socioeconomic  (e.g higher  population of ethnic minorities), health-related (e.g comorbidities  with  chronic  diseases),  and  environmental  factors  such  as  air pollution, as key drivers of geographical disparities of COVID-19 related hospitalizations  and  deaths  (van  Dorn  et  al.,  2020;  Wu  et  al.,  2020; COVID, 2020). In a previous study we found that the spatial distribution of these factors along with other spatial attributes such as airport and road connectivity were linked to the geospatial disparities of COVID-19 related risk of mortality in the U.S (Correa-Agudelo et al., 2020). Understanding the local variation in disease transmission dynamics under heterogeneous geospatial attributes is a crucial step in developing more effective strategies for mitigating risk of infection in vulnerable communities. Therefore,  in  this  study,  we  built  a  spatially-explicit mathematical  model  to  predict  the  county-level  spatial  dynamics  of COVID-19 epidemic in a region.
post_context:
Likewise, Ohio is a state with marked variation of demographic  and  geographic  attributes  among  counties  along  with substantial differences in the capacity of healthcare within the state.Our goal is to forecast the spatiotemporal patterns of the COVID-19 pandemic in Ohio while considering healthcare capacity distribution. 

To achieve this, a spatial mathematical model was developed to simulate the transmission dynamics of COVID-19 infection. The model, known as the Susceptible-Infected-Hospitalized-Recovered-Dead (SIHRD) COVID-19 model, divides the population into different categories based on their infection status. 

Geospatial attributes such as local air hubs and main roads were taken into account to stratify the model into four spatial risk groups. These groups were classified based on connectivity factors such as airport passenger numbers and proximity to main highways. By including these factors, the model was able to capture the varying risk of exposure to infection and the impact of public health interventions in each spatial group.

The non-spatial adjusted model overestimated the infection rate in Group 4 and underestimated it in Group 1. Critical healthcare capacity, measured by ICU beds available, also varied significantly across counties, with Group 1 having the highest capacity and Group 4 having the lowest.

author: enrique
pre_context: Counties in Ohio with higher air transportation connectivity experienced a quicker spread of infection compared to neighboring counties with high road connectivity or more isolated rural counties. The severity of the COVID-19 epidemic within these counties was not solely due to population distribution, but also influenced by spatial attributes such as transport connectivity. Over 47% of confirmed COVID-19 cases in Ohio were concentrated in five counties (Cleveland, Brentwood, San Lucas, Tuscaloosa, and Peak), characterized by high population density and serving as local air hubs with over 10 million passengers annually. The influx of travelers and imported infections through airports in these counties contributed to the accelerated spread of the virus locally. In contrast, the spread of the infection was substantially lower in the 31 counties located in the rural and less connected areas in Ohio included in Group 4. Although these less densely populated counties are home to only 11% of the total population in Ohio, the infection rate was more than three times lower compared to the infection rate in the local air hub counties. We also identified marked differences in the geographical distribution of the critical healthcare capacity of the state. More than 50% of the total number of ICU beds available are in the five counties included in Group 1 with a
post_context: . However, only 7% of ICU beds in the state are spread across 31 rural and less connected counties, with a rate of 10 ICU beds per 100,000 people. Despite these disparities in critical healthcare capacity, our analysis suggests that the lower transmission rates in these areas prevented overwhelming their healthcare systems. If the state maintains current interventions, only 27% of maximum critical care capacity would be reached, with some counties reaching over 50% capacity. In contrast, easing interventions would lead to 61% capacity reached statewide, with faster saturation in high transmission areas. Rural counties in Group 4 would see slower spread and less impact on critical care capacity compared to more connected areas in Group 1.

author: enrique
pre_context: The analysis revealed that the varying severity of the COVID-19 epidemic across counties in Indiana was not solely due to population distribution, but also linked to factors like transport connectivity. Over 47% of confirmed cases were concentrated in five counties (Cuyahoga, Franklin, Lucas, Montgomery, and Summit) with a high infection rate of 274 cases per 100,000 people. These counties, which are home to 35% of the state's population, also serve as major air hubs with over 10 million annual passengers. The airports in these counties can lead to a significant influx of imported infections, contributing to local transmission and hastening the spread of the virus. On the other hand, infection rates were lower in the 31 rural and less connected counties in Indiana. Although these less densely populated counties are home of only 11% of the total population in Indiana, the infection rate was more than three times lower compared to the infection rate in the local air hub counties. We also identified marked differences in the geographical distribution of the critical healthcare capacity of the state. More than 50% of the total number of ICU beds available are in the five counties included in Group 1 with a rate of 22 ICU beds per 100,000 people. In contrast, only 7% of the total number of ICU beds available in the state are distributed in the 31 counties located in the rural and less connected areas of the state, with a
post_context: . Despite variations in healthcare capacity across different regions of the state, our analysis indicates that the less connected rural counties experienced lower transmission rates, thus preventing critical care systems from becoming overwhelmed. Maintaining non-pharmaceutical interventions implemented in mid-March 2020 until early May would result in only 27% of the state's maximum critical care capacity being reached, excluding 10 counties without ICU beds. However, easing interventions by 50% could lead to 61% capacity utilization after eight weeks. Counties with higher disease transmission rates would reach capacity faster, with almost complete saturation (94%) expected within eight weeks of intervention relaxation. Conversely, rural counties with slower infection spread in Group 4 are less likely to exceed critical care capacity.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: D.F. Cuadros et al. illustrate in Figure 3 the spatiotemporal dynamics of COVID-19 cases using spatial adjusted and non-spatial adjusted models. The counties in Group 4 show a significantly lower critical care response compared to Group 1, potentially avoiding saturation of critical care facilities. Despite this, eight of the 31 counties in Group 4 do not have hospitals with ICU beds. Counties like Adams, Champaign, and Seneca are projected to reach over 60% of their maximum critical care capacity. These findings highlight the importance of targeted strategies to bolster critical care response in less connected counties and those near air hubs in Ohio in the face of the COVID-19 pandemic.Our study has several limitations worth noting. For simplification, we generated a connectivity index based only in one geospatial attribute in which airports and main roads were used as a connectivity index for each county. Other potential geospatial and population characteristics might influence transmission dynamics and improve estimated disease trajectories,  but  inclusion  of  these  factors  can  substantially  increase model complexity. Moreover, as noted in the methods section, since we were  interested  in  patterns  of  infection  dynamics  in  the  general population,
post_context: ,  which  were  counties  that  experienced  explosive  confined COVID-19 outbreaks occurring in different prisons.However, isolated outbreaks may play a significant role in the transmission of the disease and could strain local critical care capacity. It is important to note that the SIHRD COVID-19 model discussed in this study was based on data from Ohio only. The COVID-19 pandemic consists of various sub-epidemics with varying intensities, even within the same country. There have been COVID-19 outbreaks at different times and in different locations in the U.S., with each state implementing different control measures that can affect the disease dynamics. Therefore, it is crucial to evaluate the model's performance using data from other locations. Despite these limitations, this study presents one of the first spatiotemporal models of COVID-19 transmission to simulate spatial disparities in disease outcomes such as confirmed cases, hospitalizations, ICU admissions, and more.

text: In close communication with Cornell University's administration, we conducted a simulation-based analysis in summer 2020 using a compartmental Susceptible, Exposed, Infectious, and Recovered model with multiple subpopulations
author: chunwei
pre_context: Despite facing similar circumstances, various US states and national governments chose vastly different responses to the pandemic. While simulation-based epidemic models offer the potential to help make informed decisions tailored to specific settings, they are limited by the uncertainties in input parameters and the potential for exponential growth. Even small differences in factors like behavior and biology can lead to significant variations in projected case numbers. Despite these limitations, this article illustrates how simulation models can still aid in the effective selection of COVID-19 interventions, as shown through their support in designing measures at Cornell University. The presented modeling framework can also assist in decision-making at other educational institutions.(The use of epidemic models in the presence of significant parameter uncertainty is also discussed in, for example, ref. 15. In such settings, clear communication of uncertainties is key; see, for example, ref. 16).)
post_context: ; see refs.Our research guided the decision to reopen Cornell's Ithaca campus for residential instruction in fall 2020 and helped establish an asymptomatic screening program essential to Cornell's overall strategy. As a result of our modeling recommendations, a large percentage of students returned to campus for the 2020-2021 school year under this screening program. The surveillance program utilized pooled PCR testing and anterior nares (AN) sampling for student comfort and compliance. This effort was made possible through collaborative efforts and support from Cornell's College of Veterinary Medicine and a local health care provider. Our simulation modeling approach was also used to update the strategy for the spring 2021 semester and fall 2021 to adapt to changes in social distancing policies, the Delta variant, and vaccination status. Despite these challenges, the number of infections among students and employees remained low compared to other institutions with similar student populations. Our modeling approach focuses on identifying parameters that can effectively control epidemics, ensuring the success of our strategies.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: A prior probability distribution was established for parameters using independent normal distributions. The mean and variance of the prior for each parameter were selected to align with plausible ranges, resulting in a 95% Bayesian credible interval. The choice of a multivariate normal distribution as the prior was necessary for modeling and analysis purposes, as discussed in detail in the SI Appendix. Random parameter sets were then drawn from this Bayesian prior, with feasible values ensured through appropriate truncation for positive and/or bounded parameters. Simulation results formed a prior distribution over infections, addressing parameter uncertainty. While 2×/wk testing was generally effective for infection control, large outbreaks could occur under certain parameter settings. To better understand the impact of interventions like testing on robustness to parameter uncertainty, a one-dimensional family of parameter configurations was developed with varying levels of pessimism regarding infection numbers. (Methods D and SI Appendix, section 3.A).This family of parameter configurations is indexed by a pessimism level between zero and one, with larger levels corresponding to parameter configurations with more infections. The parameter configuration at pessimism level q is the most likely configuration under the prior for which median infections is equal to the q quantile of infections under the prior, assuming that infections for a given parameter configuration are given by the previously fitted linear model. Within this family, we name two for more frequent use, given in Fig. 1F: the nominal and pessimistic scenarios, corresponding to pessimism levels 0.5 and
post_context: , respectively.We refer to the latter in graphs as "pessimistic (residential)" to distinguish it from a scenario that is pessimistic about a different outcome as defined in Results D. The pessimistic scenario, compared to the nominal scenario where each parameter is set to the middle of its range, significantly increases the asymptomatic ratio and transmission rate, while decreasing test sensitivity and contact tracing effectiveness. These parameters have the greatest impact on infections. To assess the assumption of linearity in creating these scenarios, we compared the median number of infections under various pessimistic scenarios to the median infections drawn from the prior distribution. The results showed a strong agreement, suggesting that the linearity assumption had minimal impact on the level of pessimism in our scenarios. Simulated infections using 2×/wk testing across a range of pessimism levels show that testing can keep infections below 1,000 in most parameter configurations. However, in some scenarios, more than 1,000 infections can occur, especially as the parameter configuration becomes more pessimistic. Additional testing can help reduce this risk. When testing frequency is high enough, predicted infections remain low even at high levels of pessimism. Plots of infections versus test frequency and simulation parameters were presented in public reports and at Cornell Faculty Senate meetings. These reports included nominal and pessimistic scenarios similar to the ones discussed here.

author: enrique
pre_context: We conducted a Bayesian analysis to study the impact of asymptomatic testing frequency and vaccination rate during the fall 2021 semester. Parameters were adjusted based on data from the previous academic year and information on vaccine effectiveness against the Delta variant. We increased transmission rates by 2.5 times to reflect the influence of the Delta variant and included parameters for vaccine effectiveness on transmission and susceptibility. The majority of Cornell students were vaccinated, surpassing the 95% mark once international students were also vaccinated. Changes in social distancing measures, prevalence outside campus, and contact tracing protocols led to uncertainty in transmission rates and case management. We used a prior distribution for these parameters, sampled from it, conducted simulations, and updated to a posterior distribution. Parameters are altered individually for the wild-type, Alpha variant, and Delta variant. The relative changes in infections and deaths are then calculated for each variant. Parameters examined include virus infectivity, rate of infection of individuals recovered from a different variant, ratio of asymptomatic versus symptomatic infections, among others. The baseline assumption is based on Ontario vaccination data, with 95% Pfizer and 5% AstraZeneca vaccines administered. However, if a larger proportion of AstraZeneca vaccines were utilized, similar to the situation in the UK, notable differences in protection against COVID variants, particularly Delta, are observed, with Pfizer offering stronger protection. For instance, an individual having received both doses of the Pfizer vaccine is 88% protected against the Delta variant, whereas with the AstraZeneca vaccine the protection is only at 60%. We conduct a simulation in which only 40% of the vaccines are Pfizer. With a larger portion of the vaccinated population now under reduced vaccine protection, the spread of the VOC is substantially accelerated. By December 31, 2021, the model predicts
post_context: , more than three times higher than the baseline prediction of 234 new Delta infections a day (Fig. 7a). The projected total number of Delta infections and related deaths by December 31, 2021 are significantly higher at 62 K and 882, respectively, compared to the baseline values of 39 K and 689. If the vaccination rate in the province is lower, with only 67% of the population vaccinated by September 1, 2021 compared to the baseline of 74%, it is predicted that Delta infections and deaths will increase by 75% by March 2022. Ontario began reopening in mid-June 2021, with in-person classes set to resume in September. The baseline model assumes that the remaining non-pharmaceutical interventions (NPI) will still reduce COVID-19 infectivity by 60%. However, considering factors such as pandemic fatigue, increased personal interactions, and potential outbreaks in schools, it may be overly optimistic to assume that the NPI will remain as effective. Therefore, a scenario with less stringent NPI starting on September 1, 2021 is considered, with the infection rate (λ) increased from its baseline value of 0.4.

post_context: (i.e.On January 23, 2020, we define cb as the minimum contact rate in the current control strategies, and r1 as the rate at which the contact rate decreases exponentially. It is assumed that contacts decrease over time at a rate of r1, starting at c0 and decreasing to a lower limit. This, along with cb, reflects the effectiveness of public health interventions such as self-isolation for susceptible individuals. We also define dI(t) as an increasing function of time t, where the period of diagnosis decreases exponentially according to a specific formula. This rate of diagnosis is crucial in determining the resources needed in the affected area. By using time-dependent coefficients in our model, we calculate the effective daily reproduction ratio, a measure of the daily reproduction number, to track the spread of infection. Data on confirmed 2019-nCov cases provided by the National Health Commission of China is used in the parameter estimation process for our model which considers evolving public health interventions.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Individuals in the period were diagnosed at increasing rates over time. The period of diagnosis, denoted as dI(t), decreases as time t increases. The formula for dI(t) is 1/dI0 + (1/dIf - 1/dI0) * e^(r2t)/(1 + dIf). Here, dI0 represents the initial diagnosis rate at t=0, dIf is the fastest diagnosis rate over time, and r2 is the exponential rate of decrease. This rate is influenced by available resources in the epicenter. Using a formula from a previous study (Tang et al., 2020), we adjusted for time-dependent coefficients to represent evolving public health interventions and resources. text: By using time-dependent contact and diagnose rates we refit our proposed dynamics transmission model to the data available until January 29th, 2020 and re-estimated the daily reproduction number, which implies the evolving transmission risk.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Previous studies on the SARS outbreak have influenced the development of disease modelling techniques. Similarities can be seen between the SARS outbreak and the current 2019 n-Cov situation, with both having high basic reproduction numbers in specific settings. The epicenter of the current outbreak is Wuhan, a city with a large population, and the spread has extended beyond the city due to travel. The situation is rapidly evolving in Wuhan, the Hubei province, and across China. Our simulations indicate that the effectiveness of control measures relies on interventions in the field, which are dependent on resources for frontline workers and patients. The timing and magnitude of peak cases are influenced by factors such as speed of diagnosis and hospitalization.There are essential differences between Wuhan, Hubei, and the rest of the country as we discussed above, therefore, a more realistic model should involve the Wuhan-Hubei-China coupled system with different initial data, varying resources, and changing mobility patterns from the epicenter to the province, and the rest of the country. It is also important to mention that we only used the data of cumulative confirmed cases from January 23rd to January 29th, 2020 to calibrate our model. Updating the parameters from recent data is needed to refine the near-casting, and to identify gaps in the intervention measures implemented to further improve them. Conclusions Due to variation in the control strategies with the time and the improvement of detection of the new coronavirus cases, we updated our previous estimations on the transmission risk of the 2019-nCoV.
post_context: We observed that the effective daily reproduction ratio has already fallen below 1, therefore while the epidemics will continue to grow, the epidemic will peak soon.Accurately predicting the trend of an epidemic and determining the peak time requires real-time data and understanding of resources available for public health interventions. This research was funded by the National Natural Science Foundation of China and the Canada Research Chair Program. We appreciate the support from the Tianyuan Mathematical Center, Fields Institute for Research in Mathematical Sciences, and Mathematics for Public Health Laboratory. Various references provide valuable information on controlling outbreaks, including the novel coronavirus.

author: chunwei

ARNSCHEIDT,a JOHN MARSHALL,a PIERRE DUTRIEUX,b,c CRAIG D. RYE,a,d a Department of Earth, Atmospheric, and Planetary Sciences, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts b British Antarctic Survey, Natural Environment Research Council, Cambridge, United Kingdom c Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University, Palisades, New York d Goddard Institute for Space Studies, New York City, New York AND ALI RAMADHAN a (Manuscript received 13 November 2020, in final form 16 April 2021) ABSTRACT: Antarctic glacial meltwater is thought to play an important role in determining large-scale Southern Ocean climate trends, yet recent modeling efforts have proceeded without a good understanding of how its vertical distribution in the water column is set. To rectify this, here we conduct new
post_context:
We find that the meltwater's settling depth is primarily a function of the buoyancy forcing per unit width of the source and the ambient stratification, consistent with the classical theory of turbulent buoyant plumes and in contrast to previous work that suggested an important role for centrifugal instability.Our findings emphasize the important role of localized variability in stratification, which contributes to variations in vertical meltwater distribution near Pine Island Glacier. Due to the diverse mass loss rates and environmental conditions across Antarctic ice shelves, it is essential to dynamically parameterize meltwater settling depth for accurate simulations of high-latitude climate in a warming world. We explore the potential development of this parameterization in the wake of our research and address the remaining challenges. KEYWORDS: Ocean; Antarctica; Glaciers; Snowmelt/icemelt; Climate change

Introduction

One of the shortcomings of global coupled climate models included in the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project phase 5 (CMIP5; Taylor et al. 2012) is their inability to retroactively predict key Southern Ocean climate trends, such as surface cooling, surface freshening, and sea ice expansion (Turner et al. 2013; Jones et al. 2016; Kostov et al. 2018). The increase in the Antarctic meltwater anomaly in recent years may have influenced these observed trends (Rye et al. 2020). Traditionally, climate models have overlooked the abnormal freshwater flux resulting from the net mass loss from the Antarctic ice sheet, which has escalated to about 500 Gt yr in the past few decades (Paolo et al. 2015; Rignot et al. 2019). Recent research indicates that integrating this meltwater anomaly into climate models could help elucidate the observed trends and bridge the gap between observations and simulations (Bintanja et al. 2013; Rye et al. 2014; Bintanja et al. 2015; Rye et al. 2020). Additionally, the inclusion of Antarctic glacial meltwater carries significant implications.

BMC Res Notes          (2020) 13:352  https://doi.org/10.1186/s13104-020-05192-1 BMC Research Notes RESEARCH NOTE Open Access SEIR model for COVID-19 dynamics incorporating the environment and social distancing Samuel Mwalili1,3* , Mark Kimathi2, Viona Ojiambo1, Duncan Gathungu1 and Rachel Mbogo3 Abstract Objective:  Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a pandemic respiratory illness spreading from person-to-person caused by a novel coronavirus and poses a serious public health risk. The goal of this study was to apply a modified susceptible-exposed-infectious-recovered (SEIR) compartmental mathematical model for prediction of COVID-19 epidemic dynamics incorporating pathogen in the environment and interventions.
post_context: Results:  We found an R0 of 2.03, implying that the pandemic will persist in the human population in the absence of strong control measures.The results of simulations suggest that ignoring social distancing and hygiene measures can have severe consequences for the population. The model demonstrates that implementing quarantine and isolation measures can effectively stop the spread of the novel coronavirus. Coronaviruses, including SARS-CoV-2, have caused a range of illnesses, with COVID-19 declared a global pandemic by the WHO in February 2020. This study aims to develop a modified SEIR mathematical model to predict COVID-19 epidemic dynamics and assess different intervention strategies. Mathematical modeling has been used by various researchers to understand the transmission dynamics of coronaviruses such as MERS-CoV.

Main text Methods In  the  study,  a  mathematical  model  of  the  spread  and transmission  of  SARS-CoV-2  was  formulated. We  consider  two  interacting  populations,  the  human  population  as  hosts  and  the  pathogens. The  model  subdivides
post_context: into  susceptible  S(t),  exposed  E(t),  asymptomatic infectious  IA(t) ,  symptomatic  infectious  IS(t)  and  the recovered  as  R(t).The presence of the pathogen P(t) in the environment is represented by N(t) = S(t) + E(t) + IA(t) + IS(t) + R(t) for the human population. Studies have indicated that COVID-19 can spread through human-to-human and environment-to-human transmission. Infected individuals, both asymptomatic IA(t) and symptomatic IS(t), can transmit the virus to susceptible persons S(t) through close contact. Additionally, the virus can spread to the environment when infected individuals cough or sneeze without precautions, potentially exposing susceptible individuals in close proximity. Susceptible individuals exposed to the environment may become infected, especially in the early stages of the outbreak before hygiene measures are put in place. The infected individual initially moves to the exposed population E(t) due to the incubation period, and then to either asymptomatic IA(t) or symptomatic IS(t) populations. P(t) represents the quantity of pathogens during human interactions at time t. Most infected individuals recover and move to the recovered human population R(t). The compartmental model illustrating the interaction between humans and pathogens in the environment is shown in Figure 1. The parameters used in the COVID-19 transmission model can be found in Table 1, resulting in a six-dimensional system of ordinary differential equations shown in the SEIR-P model of COVID-19 transmission in Figure 1.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: In their study, Mwalili et al. (2020) explored the complex interactions between humans and their environment, conducting detailed simulation studies. The research involved developing a mathematical model for the spread and transmission of SARS-CoV-2. This model considered two populations - humans as hosts and pathogens. The human population at time t, denoted as N(t), was divided into susceptible (S(t)), exposed (E(t)), asymptomatic infectious (IA(t)), symptomatic infectious (IS(t)), and recovered (R(t)) individuals. The pathogen in the environment was labeled as P(t). It was observed that the virus could be transmitted through human-to-human contact as well as from the environment to humans. Epidemic data indicated that both asymptomatic (IA(t)) and symptomatic (IS(t)) infected individuals could spread the virus to susceptible individuals (S(t)) through close contact or when coughing or sneezing without proper precautions.Since the pathogen  P(t)  is  known  to  survive  in  the  environment  for some days, susceptible individuals S(t) in close contact to  this  environment  are  likely  to  get  exposed  to  these pathogens,  especially  in  the  early  days  of  the  COVID- 19 outbreak before hygiene protocols are implemented. In  the  process  of  disease  spread,  the  susceptible  individual first moves to the exposed population E(t) since the host has an incubation period[5]. The exposed individual  moves  to  either  asymptomatic  IA(t)  or  symptomatic  IS(t)  infectious  population. P(t)  is  the  number or  quantity  of  pathogens  present  during  interaction of  human  beings  at
post_context: The  majority  of  infectious individuals recovers and move to the recovered human population R(t).Figure 1 displays a compartmental model illustrating the relationship between the human population and pathogens in the environment. Table 1 provides the parameters utilized in the model for COVID-19 transmission. This leads to a six-dimensional system of ordinary differential equations, resulting in the SEIR-P model shown in Figure 1, depicting the human (SEIR) and pathogen (P) compartments.

post_context: respectively.During this outbreak, health experts and governments are recommending social distancing to reduce contact with infectious individuals. In our model, we suggest new infections occur due to interactions alpha 1 and alpha 2, where susceptible individuals are infected with COVID-19 from the environment and from infectious individuals. The equilibrium points and basic reproduction number of the SEIR-P model are determined by solving relevant equations. The disease-free equilibrium point, where infections are zero, is achieved when susceptible individuals are at a constant value. The basic reproduction number, R0, indicates the average number of secondary infections caused by an infected individual in a susceptible population. The next step involves using the next generation matrix approach to determine R0. By evaluating F and V at the disease-free equilibrium point, we can understand the dynamics of the spread of the infection.

post_context: and also the virus in the environment (P).Following the latency period, the number of infected individuals increases rapidly, surpassing the hospital bed capacity of 8000. Approximately 30% of infected individuals exhibit mild or no symptoms. The model parameters used in this simulation study are detailed in Table 1. Symptomatic individuals are considered to be more infectious than asymptomatic individuals, leading to increased transmission of COVID-19 in various settings. As a result, there is a surge in cases in workplaces, schools, during commutes, and in other environments. The model illustrates that the risk of infection from the environment versus infected individuals impacts the number of exposed, asymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals. When the risk from the environment is high, more individuals become infected, but when the risk from infected individuals is higher, the number of susceptible individuals decreases rapidly. Control measures such as social distancing can help reduce the number of new infections and slow the spread of the virus.

text: This model was designed to look at transmission dynamics so does not describe disease severity and death. Given we  made  assumptions  of  the  parameters  at  onset  of  the pandemic, there is a possibility that the model may overestimate the pandemic at later period of time.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The study results in Table 1 illustrate that symptomatic individuals (IS) are assumed to be more contagious than asymptomatic individuals (IA), leading to increased transmission of COVID-19 in various settings such as households, workplaces, schools, and public transport. This results in a surge of the virus in these environments, resulting in a higher number of confirmed coronavirus cases between 10 and 35 days, as shown in Fig. 2a and 2b. The model in this study uses constants α1 and α2 to represent the frequency of acquiring COVID-19 from the environment and infected individuals, respectively. When α1 = 0.05, indicating a high risk of infection from a contaminated environment, there is an increase in exposed, asymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals. Conversely, when α2 = 0.05, indicating a higher risk of infection from an individual rather than a contaminated environment, the number of susceptible individuals decreases rapidly by the 23rd day, as shown in Fig. 2c. Further details on the rapid spread of infection within the first 20 days are shown in Fig. 2d–f.Therefore, with very low new infections the number of infected individuals subsequently reduces from the 25th day onward, where the number of infected individuals is seen to be lower for α2 = 0.05 , as compared to when α1 = 0.05 and α2 = 0.1. Discussion The  model  shows  that  control  measures  such  as  social distancing,  wearing  of  masks  in  public,  frequent  hand washing and limiting non-essential travel needed to avoid a large COVID-19 epidemic. There is a growing concern that  this  disease  could  continue  to  ravage  the  human population globally since many aspects of the COVID-19 are yet to be discovered, which also poses a challenge to the long-term mathematical modeling of the disease. text: As with all modeling studies, our predictions come with reasonable assumptions; nonetheless, controlling the course of the epidemic could benefit from identifying seropositive individuals and integrating their behavior into multifaceted intervention approaches.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Intervention through serological testing with a shield immunity table involves identifying individuals who are susceptible, infectious, or recovered from a virus. The table summarizes the policy for shielding transmission based on an individual's virus and antibody status.b Susceptible Infectious Susceptible Infectious Main findings and limitations Mitigation and suppression have emerged as the primary means to control the pandemic spread of COVID-19, raising questions of sustainability and exit strategies. Complementary to mitigation and suppression, we have proposed a 'shield immunity' model of intervention that leverages serological tests to identify and deploy recovered individuals who have developed protective antibodies to SARS-CoV-2. Serological testing is essential to identifying individuals who have been infected, recovered and are immune (in the near term) to SARS-CoV-2. Several scenarios have been explored that show substantive decreases in cases, hospitalizations, and deaths compared to baseline given enhanced interactions with recovered individuals that reduce the risk of transmission.
post_context: Policy implications Our findings reinforce the need for large-scale, serological testing initiatives to identify individuals who have recovered from COVID-19.Questions persist about the duration and effectiveness of immunity, but strategically identifying and deploying recovered individuals can help reduce transmission for the greater good. Implementing large-scale serological testing initiatives is crucial for proactive measures to end the COVID-19 pandemic and facilitate economic recovery, potentially resulting in fewer than 25% of the population becoming infected, compared to the expected ~90% without protective measures. Our core shielding model serves as the foundation for applying to COVID-19, showcasing the conservative benefits of shielding. However, more detailed mixing and substitution models could offer further insights into spatially explicit areas or networks. In this study, we apply our shield immunity model to the epidemiological dynamics of the COVID-19 pandemic, focusing on susceptible, exposed, asymptomatic, symptomatic, and recovered individuals without restrictions. A portion of symptomatic cases may require hospitalization, ranging from subacute to critical cases necessitating intensive care. We anticipate a significant proportion of critical cases to result in fatalities. Age-specific risk of hospitalization and severe cases are based on data from the United Kingdom and the United States. This model, incorporating shield immunity, differs from traditional SIR models with social distancing measures.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The primary strategies to manage the spread of COVID-19 are mitigation and suppression, but questions arise about their long-term effectiveness and exit plans. In addition to these strategies, we have introduced the concept of 'shield immunity,' which utilizes serological tests to identify recovered individuals with protective antibodies against SARS-CoV-2. Serological testing is crucial for identifying immune individuals in the short term. Our simulations demonstrate significant reductions in cases, hospitalizations, and deaths by incorporating interactions with recovered individuals to decrease transmission risk. While our findings are based on assumptions, identifying seropositive individuals and incorporating their behavior into interventions could help control the epidemic.Policy implications Our findings reinforce the need for large-scale, serological testing initiatives to identify individuals who have recovered from COVID-19. Although questions remain about the duration and effectiveness of immunity, strategic identification and deployment of recovered individuals represents an opportunity to reduce transmission for the collective good. Initiating large-scale serological testing initiatives is key to proactive approaches to end the COVID-19 pandemic and enable economic re-engagement. ensuring  the  final  outbreak  concludes  with  less  than  25%  of  the population  having  been  infected  compared  to  the  expectation  of
post_context: in the absence of shielding.We base our application to COVID-19 on the core shielding model, which illustrates the conservative advantages of shielding. However, more detailed mixing and substitution models could lead to further variations, such as in specific geographic areas or on networks. In this study, we apply our shield immunity model to the epidemiological dynamics of the COVID-19 pandemic, simplifying by ignoring births and other causes of death. We consider a population consisting of susceptible (S), exposed (E), infectious asymptomatically (Ia), infectious symptomatically (Is), and recovered (R) individuals who are free to move without restrictions in a normal scenario. Some symptomatic cases will require hospital care, divided into subacute (Ihsub) and critical and/or acute cases (Ihcri) requiring ICU intervention. A portion of critical cases may result in death. The risk of hospitalization and acute cases are based on data from previous studies. The model incorporating shield immunity differs from traditional SIR models with social distancing or case isolation interventions, as transmission rate is reduced by a factor dependent on the total population and the number of recovered individuals with immunity. The model assumes all recovered individuals have immunity, but only some can facilitate interaction substitutions, and individuals in the circulating pool are not interacting with hospitalized patients.

post_context: in the baseline scenario without shielding (Fig.We also investigated 'flexible' and 'fixed' shielding as possible alternative mechanisms for interaction substitution (see Methods). In a flexible shielding mechanism, the interaction rates of recovered individuals are increased by a factor of (1 + α) compared to other individuals, while maintaining the total contact rate equal to the baseline. A fixed shielding mechanism involves increasing the interaction rates of recovered individuals by a factor of (1 + α) compared to the baseline rate, while also keeping the total contact rate the same as the baseline. Extended Data Fig. 1 demonstrates that shielding remains effective in these alternative scenarios, potentially even more so. For instance, in a scenario of fixed shielding with α = 3, recovered individuals have four times as many contacts as their pre-intervention baseline.

post_context:
and other measures were implemented. The results shown in Figure 3 compare the impact of different shielding interventions on epidemic outcomes. Similar to the simple SIR model, shielding alone has the potential to reduce the overall burden of the epidemic, decreasing both the total number of cases and shortening the peak period. In a population of 10,000,000 in a high-transmission scenario, the baseline prediction is 71,000 deaths, while intermediate shielding (α = 2) lowers this to 58,000 deaths, and enhanced shielding (α = 20) reduces it to 20,000 deaths. In a low-transmission scenario with the same population size, the baseline prediction is 50,000 deaths, but this decreases to 34,000 deaths with intermediate shielding and 8,300 deaths with enhanced shielding.

Most of the deaths occur in individuals aged 60 years and older, despite them making up a smaller fraction of the population. This aligns with findings from other COVID-19 models and outbreaks in Italy and India. While our simulation only considers the effects of shielding, ongoing restrictions like social distancing will further decrease interaction rates. The success of shielding depends on the number of potential shields identified and their ability to effectively substitute interactions, denoted as αRshields.

Population-wide impacts of shielding are influenced by various factors such as demographic distributions, the fraction of asymptomatic transmission, and the duration of immunity. Our findings suggest that populations with a higher proportion of older individuals may benefit more from shielding. Despite fewer recovered individuals between the ages of 20 and 60, the benefits of shielding remain significant.

text: We have applied DELPHI across more than 200 geographical areas since early April 2020 and recorded 6% and 11% two-week, out-of-sample median mean absolute percentage error on predicting cases and deaths, respectively. DELPHI compares favorably with other top COVID-19 epidemiological models and predicted in 2020 the large-scale epidemics in many areas, including the United States, United Kingdom, and Russia, months in advance.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The journal Operations Research, volume 71, issue 1, published in January-February 2023, can be accessed at the following link: https://pubsonline.informs.org/journal/opre.184–201 ISSN 0030-364X (print), ISSN 1526-5463 (online) Crosscutting Areas Forecasting COVID-19 and Analyzing the Effect of Government Interventions Michael Lingzhi Li,a Hamza Tazi Bouardi,a Omar Skali Lami,a Thomas A. Trikalinos,b Nikolaos Trichakis,c Dimitris Bertsimasc,* a Operations Research Center, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02139; b Center for Evidence Synthesis in Health, Brown University, Providence, Rhode Island 02912; c Sloan School of Management, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02142 *Corresponding author Contact: mlli@mit.edu, oskali@mit.edu, (TAT); ntrichakis@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8208-3035 (OSL); thomas_trikalinos@brown.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8324-9148 (NT); dbertsim@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2456-4834 (MLL); htazi@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-3990-1848 https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1985-1003 (DB) https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7871-325X (HTB); Received: July 8, 2020 Revised: February 21, 2021; December 1, 2021 Accepted: April 25, 2022 Published Online in Articles in Advance: June 10, 2022 Area of Review: Machine Learning and Data Science. https://doi.org/10.1287/opre.2022.2306 Copyright: © 2022 INFORMS Abstract. We developed DELPHI, a novel epidemiological model for predicting detected cases and deaths in the prevaccination era of the COVID-19 pandemic. The model allows for underdetection of infections and effects of government interventions.
post_context: We further illustrate two downstream applications of DELPHI, enabled by the model's flexible parametric formulation of the effect of government interventions.Initially, we analyze the impact of government interventions on the spread of the pandemic. Our predictions indicate that without any interventions, over 14 million people would have died by May 17, 2020. Implementing interventions one week earlier could have prevented 280,000 deaths globally. We also observed that measures like restricting mass gatherings and closing schools led to significant reductions in infection rates, while the most effective policy was stay-at-home orders, resulting in a 74.4% reduction in infection rates. Additionally, we showcase how the DELPHI model can forecast COVID-19 incidence under different government policies, highlighting its use by Janssen Pharmaceuticals in selecting trial locations for their vaccine candidate Ad26.Cov2.S. The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has been one of the deadliest in history, with over 530 million confirmed cases and 6.3 million deaths as of June 1, 2022. In March 2020, DELPHI was developed as an extension of the traditional SEIR model to address underdetection of infections and assess the impact of interventions. DELPHI has been consistently integrated into the CDC's ensemble forecast.
