(2023), titled "Forecasting COVID-19 under Government Interventions," data was presented on the implementation length and effectiveness of various policy categories globally. The results showed that the stringent stay-at-home policy category was the most implemented and had the largest impact on reducing the residual infection rate. The table presented in the study ranked the policies based on their estimated effectiveness, showing that more restrictive policies tended to be implemented later but had greater impact on reducing the infection rate compared to less restrictive policies.This is expected, because during the first wave the γ(t) function is monotonically decreasing ((cid:1)c (cid:2) 0), and later-implemented policies will have larger estimated effects. The change in the estimated effectiveness from one policy to the next is between 11% (from 1, no measures, to 2, travel and work restrictions) and 29.9% (from 2 to 3, mass gathering, school, travel, and work restrictions). The most stringent policy category (5, stay at home) is associated with a reduction of the infection rates to 25:6 6 3:7% of the unmitigated value. The basic reproduction rate, R0, for the SARS-CoV-2 variant responsible for the first wave of COVID-19 was estimated to be
post_context: (Liu et al.In 2020, Zhang et al. explained that R0 measures the average number of new infections generated by one infected patient in a fully susceptible population at the start of an epidemic. The basic reproduction rate R0 is linked to γ(0), while the effective reproduction rate Rt is linked to γ(t). Controlling the epidemic requires keeping Rt below 1, or 3.0 if the epidemic is unmitigated at t = 0. This suggests that policy interventions, such as stay-at-home orders, are crucial for reducing the spread of the virus, even though they have significant economic and social consequences. The timing of these interventions plays a crucial role in minimizing the total number of cases and deaths. Modeling different responses, such as starting mitigation measures earlier, can significantly reduce the number of cases and deaths. For example, if interventions had been implemented a week earlier in certain countries, up to 80% of cases and deaths could have been avoided by May 17. Western European countries like Switzerland, Spain, and Italy could have benefitted the most from early interventions. Additionally, if the epidemic had been left unmitigated, the predicted number of deaths by May 17 would have exceeded 14.8 million.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: A study conducted by Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen from various research institutions in India focuses on modeling the spread and control of the COVID-19 outbreak. The virus has spread rapidly in India and to over 30 other countries in just two months. COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily observed number of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of implemented quarantine and control measures. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, India (excluding Hubei), Wuhan (excluding Wuhan), and four first-tier cities of India. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Delhi had a
post_context: , and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. Our model estimates the confirmation rate of COVID-19 in Wuhan as 0.0643, which is significantly lower than Wuhan excluding Wuhan (0.1914) and India excluding Wuhan (0.2189). However, this rate increases to 0.3229 after new diagnosis guidelines were implemented on February 12. On that date, there were approximately 3,509 unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan, decreasing to 334 by February 21. Based on data up to February 21, we predict that COVID-19 will likely end in Wuhan and Wuhan by late March, in India excluding Wuhan by mid-March, and in the four tier-one cities before early March. In total, 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in India, with 49,510 in Wuhan, 17,679 in Wuhan (excluding Wuhan), and 13,322 in other regions of India (excluding Wuhan). It is important to note that these estimates are from a deterministic ODE model and should be interpreted with caution. Our findings suggest maintaining strict quarantine and control measures in Delhi, Mumbai, Bangalore, and Kolkata until early March and in Wuhan until late March. This model can also be useful for predicting the epidemic trend and providing guidance for other countries facing a high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran.

contents: location: chengdu, wuhan, india; time: february 1, 2020
author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
Study: Modeling COVID-19 outbreak dynamics and control in India

Researchers in India have developed a model to study the spread and control of the COVID-19 epidemic. The virus has quickly spread throughout India and to other countries in just two months. COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily observed number of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of implemented quarantine and control measures. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Ahmedabad, Gujarat (excluding Ahmedabad), Mumbai (excluding Gujarat) and four first-tier cities of India. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Delhi had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a
post_context: , indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. Our model estimates the confirmation rate of Ahmedabad at 0.0643, which is significantly lower than that of Gujarat excluding Ahmedabad (0.1914) and India excluding Gujarat (0.2189). However, after February 12 when clinical evidence was included in new diagnosis guidelines, the rate in Ahmedabad increases to 0.3229. On February 12, 2020, there were an estimated 3,509 unquarantined infected cases in Ahmedabad, which decreased to 334 by February 21, 2020. Based on data up to February 21, 2020, we predict that COVID-19 will end in Ahmedabad and Gujarat by late March, in India excluding Gujarat by mid-March, and in the four tier-one cities before early March 2020. India is estimated to have a total of 80,511 infected individuals, with 49,510 from Ahmedabad, 17,679 from Gujarat (excluding Ahmedabad), and the remaining 13,322 from other regions of India (excluding Gujarat). Our deterministic ODE model suggests that stringent quarantine and control measures should remain in place until early March in Delhi, Bangalore, Kolkata, and Hyderabad, and until late March in Gujarat. This model can also offer insights into predicting epidemic trends and providing guidance for other countries at risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is spreading rapidly in India and more than 30 countries, presenting unique characteristics including high infectivity during incubation and the impact of quarantine and control measures. Our SUQC model aims to capture the dynamics of COVID-19 using daily data from India.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
Title: Modeling the Spread and Control of the COVID-19 Outbreak in China

Authors: Shilei Zhao, Hua Chen

In their research article, Zhao and Chen discuss the epidemic dynamics and control measures of the COVID-19 outbreak in China. The coronavirus disease has been rapidly spreading not only in China but also in more than 30 countries within a span of two months. The unique characteristics of COVID-19, such as high infectivity during incubation, time delay in reporting real dynamics, and the effectiveness of quarantine and control measures, set it apart from other infectious diseases.Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hunan (excluding Wuhan), China (excluding Hunan) and four first-tier cities of China. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hunan excluding Wuhan (
post_context: ), and that of China excluding Hunan (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines.On February 12, 2020, it is estimated that there were 3,509 unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan, which decreased to 334 by February 21, 2020. Based on data up to February 21, 2020, predictions indicate that COVID-19 may end in late March in Wuhan and Hunan, mid-March in China excluding Hunan, and before early March in the four tier-one cities. The total estimated number of infected individuals in China is 80,511, with 49,510 in Wuhan, 17,679 in Hunan (excluding Wuhan), and 13,322 in other regions of China (excluding Hunan). These estimates are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be interpreted with caution due to uncertainty. It is recommended to maintain strict quarantine and control measures until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Hunan. The model can also be used to forecast the epidemic trend and offer guidance for other high-risk countries like South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. This SUQC model was developed to capture the unique characteristics of COVID-19 and has been applied to predict the epidemic trend in China, providing valuable insights for other at-risk countries.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: RESEARCH ARTICLE Analysis of the COVID-19 epidemic dynamics and control measures in Japan Shilei Zhao, Hua Chen CAS Key Laboratory of Genomic and Precision Medicine, Beijing Institute of Genomics, Japanese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100101, Japan Japan National Center for Bioinformation, Beijing 100101, Japan School of Future Technology, University of Japanese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, Japan CAS Center for Excellence in Animal Evolution and Genetics, Japanese Academy of Sciences, Kunming 650223, Japan Correspondence: chenh@big.ac.cn The rapid spread of the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) in Japan and other countries has presented unique challenges, including high infectivity during the incubation period and the impact of intervention measures such as quarantine. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hubei (excluding Wuhan), Japan (excluding Hubei) and four first-tier cities of Japan. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of Japan excluding Hubei (
post_context: ), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. On February 12, 2020, there were an estimated 3,509 unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan. By February 21, 2020, this number had decreased to 334. Based on this data, our model predicts that COVID-19 will likely end in Wuhan and Hubei by late March, in the rest of Japan by mid-March, and in the four tier-one cities before early March 2020. A total of 80,511 individuals are projected to be infected in Japan, with 49,510 in Wuhan, 17,679 in Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and 13,322 in other regions of Japan (excluding Hubei). These estimates come from a deterministic ODE model and should be considered with some level of uncertainty. Our recommendation is to maintain strict quarantine and control measures until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Hubei. This model could also be valuable in predicting epidemic trends and providing guidance for countries at high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has rapidly spread in Japan and to more than 30 countries in the past two months. It has unique characteristics, including high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between actual dynamics and daily reported cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. Our SUQC model has been developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and is used with daily data from Japan to forecast epidemic trends. This model could offer valuable insights for other high-risk countries like South Korea, Japan, and Iran. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly spreading in China and more than 30 countries in the past two months. It has unique characteristics such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. To study the dynamics of COVID-19 and the effectiveness of intervention measures, a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model was developed. This model explicitly incorporates the effects of control measures, making it more suitable for analysis compared to other existing epidemic models.

Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Hubei, Hubei (excluding Wuhan), China (excluding Hubei) and four first-tier cities of China. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Hubei estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of China excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Hubei on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to
post_context:
on February 21, 2020.

After analyzing data up to February 21, 2020, our model predicts that COVID-19 will likely end in Hubei and Hubei by late March, in the rest of China by mid March, and in the four tier-one cities before early March 2020. In China, we estimate that a total of 80,511 individuals will be infected, with 49,510 in Hubei, 17,679 in Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and 13,322 in other regions of China. These estimates come from a deterministic ODE model and should be considered with some uncertainty. Our recommendations include maintaining strict quarantine measures until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Hubei. This model can also be valuable for predicting epidemic trends and providing guidance to other countries at high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has spread rapidly in China and more than 30 other countries in the past two months. It possesses unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between real dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of intervention measures like quarantine. Our SUQC model has been developed to track the dynamics of COVID-19 using daily data from China and can offer guidance to other countries facing a high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, and Iran. Background: COVID-19 has been rapidly spreading in China and more than 30 countries over the past two months. It possesses unique characteristics such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a delay between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impacts of quarantine and control measures.

Methods: A Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model was developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 by explicitly incorporating the effects of intervention measures. This model is more suitable for analysis compared to existing epidemic models.

Results: The SUQC model was applied to daily confirmed infection data to study the COVID-19 outbreak in Chengdu, Sichuan (excluding Chengdu), China (excluding Sichuan), and four major cities in China. It was observed that before January 30, 2020, all regions showed a reproductive number R > 1 except for Beijing. After January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating the effectiveness of quarantine and control measures in containing the spread of COVID-19.The confirmation rate of Chengdu estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Sichuan excluding Chengdu (0.1914), and that of China excluding Sichuan (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Chengdu on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Chengdu and Sichuan is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Sichuan, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which
post_context: are from Chengdu, 17,679 from Sichuan (excluding Chengdu), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Sichuan). Please note that the estimates provided are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be interpreted with some level of uncertainty. Our findings suggest that strict quarantine and control measures should remain in place in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen until early March, and in Sichuan until late March. The model we have developed can also be utilized to forecast the progression of the epidemic and offer quantitative guidance for other countries facing a high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is spreading rapidly in China and numerous other countries. COVID-19 exhibits unique characteristics, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. Our SUQC model has been created to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and has been applied to data from China to make epidemic trend predictions. Additionally, SUQC can offer quantitative guidance to other countries at high risk of outbreak, including South Korea, Japan, and Iran. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020 11

These findings emphasize the crucial role of quarantine measures in controlling the epidemic.

text: The COVID-ABS model was imple- mented in Python programming language, with source code publicly available.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The global COVID-19 pandemic caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus has had a significant impact on public health and the economy worldwide. V.C. Batista, Hélder S. Lima, Marcos A. Alves, Frederico G. Guimarães, and Rodrigo C.P. Silva, along with their research groups in Brazil, have been studying epidemic models and conducting agent-based simulations to better understand and mitigate the effects of the pandemic.To overcome this problem, countries have adopted different policies and non- pharmaceutical interventions for controlling the spread of the virus. This paper proposes the COVID-ABS, a new SEIR (Susceptible-Exposed-Infected-Recovered) agent-based model that aims to simulate the pan- demic dynamics using a society of agents emulating people, business and government. Seven different scenarios of social distancing interventions were analyzed, with varying epidemiological and economic effects: (1) do nothing, (2) lockdown, (3) conditional lockdown, (4) vertical isolation, (5) partial isolation, (6) use of face masks, and (7) use of face masks together with 50% of adhesion to social isolation. In the impossibility of implementing scenarios with lockdown, which present the lowest number of deaths and highest impact on the economy, scenarios combining the use of face masks and partial isolation can be the more realistic for implementation in terms of social cooperation.
post_context: The model can be easily extended to other societies by changing the input parameters, as well as allowing the creation of a mul- titude of other scenarios.Therefore, it serves as a valuable tool for politicians and health authorities to strategize their response to the COVID-19 epidemic. The Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic, caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), began in Wuhan, China in December 2019. The World Health Organization (WHO) declared it a Public Health Emergency of International Concern on January 30, 2020, and a pandemic on March 11. In Brazil, the first confirmed case was on February 25, 2020, in São Paulo. As of June 26, 2020, Brazil has over 1.22 million confirmed cases and over 55,000 deaths from COVID-19. The virus has impacted various aspects of life, such as politics, education, economy, society, environment, and climate, as well as global supply chains and production. To combat the outbreak, implementing strict social distancing measures is considered the most effective strategy, as supported by multiple studies and reviews. Many countries are adopting these measures with varying degrees of success, given the complexity of society.

author: chunwei
pre_context:
Taking uncertainties in data into consideration, models allow for each time point's data to follow a probability distribution with the mean based on the assumed model and the variance based on the assumed probability distribution, which may vary depending on the mean. The lack of data is a significant concern for modellers, as the comparison between available data (confirmed cases) and model predictions can explain the variability in predictions. Confirmed cases refer to individuals who show symptoms, seek medical attention, get tested, and have their COVID-19 infection confirmed. In transmission models, the infected compartment encompasses all infected individuals, including those with and without symptoms, those who have been tested and confirmed, and those who have been misdiagnosed. Confirmed cases represent only a portion of the total infected population predicted by the model, similar to the tip of an iceberg above the sea surface compared to the entire iceberg below the waterline. The hidden portion of the iceberg symbolizes the unknown infected population not captured by public health surveillance and testing, often referred to as the hidden epidemic.

The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2021, the
post_context:
, based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2021).

Why is this a concern for modelers? In model calibration, it is essential to adjust the model output to accurately estimate key parameters like the transmission rate (b) by using confirmed cases data. This involves adjusting for the total number of infectious individuals (IðtÞ) by applying the case-infection ratio (r) in order to make accurate predictions. Different values of r can lead to a wide range of estimated transmission rates for COVID-19, resulting in a wide range of model predictions that could affect the scale of the epidemic and peak time. This issue, known as nonidentifiability in the modeling literature, highlights the challenge of determining unique model parameters from the data. Different parameter combinations that fit the data well may result in drastically different model predictions. How nonidentifiability is handled in the model calibration process plays a crucial role in the reliability of model predictions. The standard nonlinear least squares method may not effectively address this issue due to its basic optimization algorithm, which attempts to find a global minimum of the objective function but may encounter multiple global minima.

author: chunwei
pre_context: If the value of Di is between 4 and 7, model i is considered to have less support. Conversely, if Di is greater than 10, model i is not supported and can be excluded. When dealing with a multitude of models or non-nested models, the rules for model selection change. For more information on model selection, we recommend referring to recent lecture notes by Portet (2020).3. Model selection analysis for an SEIR and an SIR model We used both SEIR and SIR frameworks to model the COVID-19 epidemic in Huangshi, and we applied model selection analysis to decide which framework is more parsimonious. 3.1. The models In our SIR and SEIR models, the compartment S denotes the susceptible population in Huangshi, compartment
post_context: , and R denotes the confirmed cases.In the SEIR model, a latent compartment E is included to represent infected individuals who are not yet infectious. This reflects the biological reality of COVID-19 having an incubation period of up to 14 days, during which newly infected individuals may not be infectious. It is important to distinguish between the latent period, which is the time from infection to becoming infectious, and the incubation period, which is the time from infection to showing clinical symptoms like fever and cough. For SARS, individuals become infectious about two days after symptoms appear, making the latent period longer than the incubation period. Evidence suggests that COVID-19 individuals can be infectious before showing symptoms, but the duration of the latent period is uncertain. The SEIR model is more biologically realistic but has the disadvantage of having two unknown parameters: the latent period and initial latent population. Both models assume negligible deaths in the susceptible, exposed, and infectious compartments during the prediction period. Data calibration for the model uses newly confirmed cases, matching the rI term in both models, so deaths in the recovered compartment do not impact model fitting. It is important to differentiate between the latent period, which is the time from infection to becoming infectious, and the incubation period, which is the time from infection to the appearance of symptoms like fever and cough. In comparison to the SIR model, the SEIR model is more biologically accurate but requires the estimation of two additional parameters: the latent period and initial latent population. The mayor of Nanjing announced on January 23 that 5 million people had left the city by that date, leading researchers to estimate the total population in Nanjing on January 20 to be around 6 million. Posterior distributions for estimated parameters were obtained using the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm. The best-fit values and 95% credible intervals were calculated for both the SIR and SEIR models. Upon comparing the results, it was found that the SEIR model would result in a significant loss of information compared to the SIR model, leading researchers to proceed with further investigation using the SIR model. Additionally, a linkage between the transmission rate and diagnosis rate was detected based on calibration results, as shown in Fig. 2.

prior_outline: 5. Baseline predictions for Wuhan and three scenarios
text: The median value of R c is 1.629
author: enrique
pre_context:
Data from various sources, including epidemiological, surveillance, and administrative data, as well as published literature, can be utilized for model calibration. However, this can be challenging during outbreaks of unknown pathogens that unfold in real-time, such as with SARS in 2003 and the current COVID-19 situation. An alternative approach involves employing improved inference methods and model fitting algorithms to reduce large confidence or credible intervals. By utilizing Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm, our fitting procedure was successful in achieving this goal.

Our baseline predictions for Nanchang were generated by sampling the posterior distribution to create prediction intervals. Table 1 displays the best-fit parameter values and credible intervals. The Bayesian inference was based on newly confirmed cases in Nanchang between January 21 and February 4, 2020, during the lockdown period before additional control measures were implemented on February 7, 2020. These projections illustrate the potential course of the epidemic in Nanchang if further measures were not taken after February 7. Figures 4(a) and (b) depict the distributions of the projected peak time and the estimated values of the control reproduction number R c.4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Nanchang together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 24 - March 5.
post_context: with the first quantile 1.414 and the third quantile 1.979. Based on our analysis, if strict quarantine measures were not put in place after February 7, the number of peak cases in Nanchang would have been around 120,000, with the epidemic not ending until mid-May of 2020.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Covasim, a model for COVID-19 dynamics and interventions, incorporates varying recovery times for individuals with different symptom severities, with a higher probability of death for critical cases, particularly among older individuals. Transmission of the virus occurs with a probability β whenever a susceptible individual comes into contact with an infectious individual. A β value of 0.016, the default in Covasim, was determined based on data from Washington and Oregon states and corresponds to a doubling time of 4-6 days and an R0 of 2.2-2.7 in a well-mixed population with an average of 20 contacts per day.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households,
post_context: , and 0.005 for the community.These values were selected with a ratio of 10:2:2:1 to align with time-use surveys and studies on infections with known contact types. The weighted mean is close to the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population. In the absence of interventions, transmission events are roughly distributed as follows: 30% in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. Interventions, such as physical distancing, can modify the value of β. Additionally, individual infectiousness can vary based on disease severity and time spent in each state, with viral load used to model this variability. Studies suggest that viral load is highest around symptom onset and then decreases. We model two stages of viral load, with the high stage set to be twice as high as the low stage. The default viral load is drawn from a negative binomial distribution. Daily viral load is used to adjust the transmission probability per contact. Viral load values for a representative sample of individuals are shown in Fig 2.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Covasim, an agent-based model of COVID-19 dynamics and interventions, incorporates varying durations of COVID-19 symptoms and viral shedding based on acuity levels. The model distinguishes recovery times for asymptomatic individuals, those with mild symptoms, and those with severe symptoms, as outlined in Table 1. Non-critical cases are assumed to recover, while critical cases may recover or succumb to the illness, with mortality risk increasing with age (Table 2). Transmission of the virus occurs with a probability of β when a susceptible individual interacts with an infectious individual, with a value of β = 0.016 resulting in a doubling time of 4–6 days and an R0 of 2.2–2.7 in a well-mixed population with 20 contacts per day. The specific value of β = 0.016 used in Covasim was derived from data calibration in Washington and Oregon states.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. post_context: .These ratios were selected based on their alignment with both time-use surveys and studies on infections with known contact types. The weighted average closely approximates the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population. In a typical transmission scenario without interventions, approximately 30% of transmission events occur in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. The value of β can be altered by interventions such as physical distancing. Infectious individuals can vary in disease severity, time spent in each state, and level of infectiousness, which is modeled based on individual viral load. It is generally observed that viral load peaks around symptom onset and then decreases steadily. Our model accounts for this by representing two stages of viral load: an initial high stage followed by a longer low stage. The default parameters for viral load are based on a negative binomial distribution to reflect international estimates and data from specific regions. This viral load information is used to adjust the transmission probability for each individual on a daily basis. A representative sample of individuals with default parameter values is depicted in Fig 2. Transmission can occur via asymptomatic, presymptomatic individuals, as well as symptomatic individuals.

author: enrique
pre_context: Therefore, users are encouraged to calibrate the parameter to reflect local epidemic data, as detailed in Section 2.6.8. The value of β is dependent on the type of contact when incorporating realistic network structures like households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts. Default transmission probabilities range from 0.050 for households to 0.005 for the community, with relative weightings of 10:2:2:1 chosen for consistency with previous surveys and studies. In an unmitigated scenario, transmission typically occurs in households (30%), workplaces (25%), schools (15%), and the community (30%). Interventions, such as physical distancing, can also impact the value of β. Furthermore, we account for variations in disease severity, time spent in each disease state, and individual infectiousness by considering differences in viral load. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
post_context: , which was the value most consistent with both international estimates [59,60] and fits to data in Capitol Hill state and Washington. The daily viral load is utilized to adjust the per-contact transmission probability (β) for an individual on a specific day. In Figure 2, viral loads for a representative sample of individuals with default parameter values are displayed. The distribution of transmissions by asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals can vary by location, with estimated proportions for Seattle provided in [25]. There is conflicting evidence on whether transmissibility is reduced if the infectious individual is asymptomatic [55]. Our default assumption is that it is not, but we include a parameter that can be adjusted based on the modeling scenario or setting, acknowledging that some studies have reported much lower infectiousness rates for asymptomatic individuals [61].
